University of Leicester http://www2.le.ac.uk These are the search results for the query, showing results 1 to 13. Aperture Photometry Tool http://www2.le.ac.uk/offices/itservices/ithelp/my-computer/programs/aperture-photometry-tool Aperture Photometry Tool (APT) is software for astronomical research, as well as for learning, visualizing and refining aperture-photometry analyses. More information

Image overlays, graphical representations, statistics, models, options and controls for aperture-photometry calculations are brought together into a single software.

Availability

  • Install using the Program installer for University PCs
  • Available for home use only for purposes of research and education in astronomy and astrophysics. Check the terms and conditions before you download

Help and Training

  • Tutorial on Aperture Photometry Tool
  • Features and functions
  • Frequently Asked Questions

License Details

Version: 2.4.7

Supplier: Aperture Photometry Tool

License: Free for use in astronomical research and education only

Restrictions

Physics members only.

]]> No publisher rfg15 data analysis research specialist 2015-01-26T10:50:00Z Blog Entry Research Grant Success for School of Education Student http://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/education/news-and-events/news-items/research-grant-success-for-school-of-education-student School of Education student successfully receives doctoral grant for language testing. Kunlaphak Kongsuwannakul receives a 2015 TOEFL Doctoral Grant to study the validity of a new item type for language tests.

Kunlaphak Kongsuwannakul (pictured) has won a grant from Educational Testing Service (ETS) in the United States to pursue her research into new item types. ETS is the world\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds largest provider of language tests, including the Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL). This is the fourth doctoral grant to be won by students in the School of Education, all of whom are supervised by Professor Glenn Fulcher. Other recipients have been Jong-Il Yi (2011), Kevin Browne (2012), and Nathaniel Owen (2014).

Kunlaphak\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds research investigates the construct validity of concordance-based cloze testing (ConCloze). ConCloze measures grammatical competence, word associates, semantic prosodies, and higher-order linguistic competence. If the research successfully establishes the abilities that learners need to successfully respond to the item, it may become established on future tests of English as a Second Language.

]]> No publisher jdb18 Doctoral Training Education phd research research 2015-01-06T10:40:00Z Blog Entry Criminology Research Internship http://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/criminology/news-and-events/criminology-research-internship The Department of Criminology is offering a six-month internship position that will give a University of Leicester graduate an exciting opportunity to be involved in two major research projects.

The first is an ESRC-funded study of hate crime, led by Dr Neil Chakraborti, and the second project focuses on probation and is led by Professor Carol Hedderman. These placements will run for three months each and would run consecutively, giving the successful applicant a rich and diverse set of research skills that will be of benefit to their future employment prospects.\ufffd\ufffd

The internship position is paid at \ufffd\ufffd14,520 pro rata and is open to University of Leicester 2013 first degree graduates who are eligible to work in the UK from July/August 2013 until January 2014.

The closing date for applications is 30 June 2013.\ufffd\ufffd

Further details about the internship role, the research projects and the person specification are available here\ufffd\ufffd

To apply, please visit the University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds My Careers page at https://mycareers.le.ac.uk/home.html

]]> No publisher rk191 research Criminology Interns College:Arts Graduation student crime Vacancies crim Undergraduate Research University of Leicester sociology Student College:SocSci students Sociology 2013-06-11T13:10:00Z Blog Entry Research in Psychology at the University of Leicester http://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/psychology/research/research Research in Psychology at the University of Leicester \ufffd\ufffd

The School of Psychology aims to undertake internationally leading research within the broad areas of cognition, neuroscience, vision, developmental psychology and social psychology. We have an interdisciplinary research approach in which both fundamental and applied research questions are investigated.

As part of the College of Medicine, Biological Sciences and Psychology, our research benefits from extensive collaborations with basic scientists, epidemiologists, health psychologists, ophthalmologists, and clinical practitioners. In addition we work with a significant number of government, public sector and industry partners including education providers, services allied to health and the legal system.

Our overarching research aim is to promote active research collaborations at both a national and international level.


\ufffd\ufffd


Judgment\ufffd\ufffdand Decision Making

Memory, Attention and Spatial Cognition

]]> No publisher pcweb1 psychology research 2012-06-12T10:15:00Z Page Write-N-Cite toolbar http://www2.le.ac.uk/offices/itservices/ithelp/my-computer/programs/write-n-cite-toolbar Write-N-Cite toolbar is used in conjunction with the online Refworks to create a bibliography and add references to your Word documents. More information

Write-N-Cite is used in conjunction with the online Refworks bibliographical reference system to create bibliographies and add references to your Word documents. It will appear as an Add-in tab on the ribbon in Word.

Availability

Pre-installed on University PCs.

Help and Training

  • Getting started with Write-N-Cite
  • Write-N-Cite online support

License Details

Version: 4

Supplier: RefWorks

Licence: University licence

Restriction

Available for student only on a University PC.

]]> No publisher mh329 students general research referencing 2012-03-09T16:05:00Z Blog Entry Stata (Intercooled) http://www2.le.ac.uk/offices/itservices/ithelp/my-computer/programs/stata-intercooled Stata is a sophisticated data analysis, data management and graphing program. More information

Stata is a complete, integrated statistical package that provides everything you need for data analysis, data management, and graphics. Intercooled Stata allows datasets with as many as 2,047 variables. The following features are available: data management, basic statistics, linear models, graphics, time series, test, predictions and effects, longitudinal data and more.

Note: Researchers with large data sets or with a large number of variables should consider using the more capable version of Stata on the ALICE service, particularly as this service is available off-campus.

Availability

Install using the Program Installer for University PCs.

Help and Training

  • Stata online support
  • State FAQs

License Details

Version: 13

Supplier: Timberlake Consultants Limited

Licence: University Research has 20 licences. University Teaching has 70 licences.

Restrictions

There are two versions available:

  • Teaching: This version must not be used for research as doing so breaches the University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds license agreement.
  • Research: This version must only be used for research as using it for teaching has significant cost implications for the University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds licensing of this software. The Research version of Stata is the same as teaching version but regular updates are applied.
]]> No publisher mh329 statistics teaching graphics staff specialist data analysis research students 2012-03-09T16:05:00Z Blog Entry SPSS http://www2.le.ac.uk/offices/itservices/ithelp/my-computer/programs/spss Statistical package for the social sciences which can handle large amounts of data. It offers a wide range of data analysis capabilities and produces results as reports or graphs. AMOS v22 is also included which allows structural equation modelling. More information

SPSS (Statistical Package for Social Sciences) allows for in-depth data access and preparation, analytical reporting, graphics and modelling.

Availability

  • Install using the Program Installer for University PCs
  • Available for home use. Check the terms and conditions before you download

Help and Training

  • SPSS online support
  • SPSS tutorials.\ufffd\ufffdThese were\ufffd\ufffdcreated by Patrick White in Sociology for his students and cover basic data handling and analysis

Training Available:

  • SPSS: Data Management and Introduction
  • SPSS: Describing and Exploring Data

License Details

Version: 22

Supplier: SPSS UK Ltd

Licence: University licence

Restriction

This program will not work off-campus for those using a IT Services managed laptop.

]]> No publisher mh329 for home research unavailable on laptops data analysis statistics general staff students 2012-03-09T16:05:00Z Blog Entry NVivo http://www2.le.ac.uk/offices/itservices/ithelp/my-computer/programs/nvivo NVivo is designed to assist in the analysis of qualitative data, enabling researchers to analyse items such as questionnaires, transcripts of interviews and focus groups. More information

NVivo can also help analyse audio and video recordings as well as digitized pictures.

NVivo handles most data, including Word documents, PDFs, audio files, database tables, spreadsheets, videos and pictures. NVivo lets you work with information in any combination of languages. Query tools let you search for an exact word or words that are similar in meaning to test theories.

You can use annotations to jot down thoughts, create memos to capture detailed observations or use links to \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdglue\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd items with similar themes together. NVivo lets you display connections, ideas and findings using a range of visualization tools such as charts, maps and models. Your conclusions, query results, models and charts can all be exported into reports and presentations.

Availability

  • Pre-installed on student University PCs
  • Install using the Program Installer for staff University PCs
  • Available for home use. Check the terms and conditions before you download

Help and Training

  • NVivo online support
  • NVivo FAQs

Training available:

  • Introducing NVivo
  • Exploiting NVivo

License Details

Version: 10

Supplier: QSR International Pty Ltd.

Licence: University licence

]]> No publisher mh329 data analysis general staff research for home students 2012-03-09T16:05:00Z Blog Entry EndNote http://www2.le.ac.uk/offices/itservices/ithelp/my-computer/programs/endnote EndNote is a program that allows you to organise your references and format them in the reference style of your choice. It includes a Word add-in to so that you can cite while you write. More information

EndNote is a bibliographic reference manager program that allows you to organise your references and format them in the reference style of your choice. Create your bibliographies automatically by inserting references from your EndNote reference library into Word.

Refworks is an alternative reference manager available online and is free for home use.

Availability

  • Install using the Program Installer for University PCs
  • Available for home use. Check the terms and conditions before you download

Help and Training

Help and training can be found on the Library website.

License Details

Version: Staff: X7.1; Students: X7

Supplier: Thomson ResearchSoft

Licence: University licence

Restriction

Available only on a University PC.

]]> No publisher mh329 students referencing research staff specialist 2012-03-09T16:05:00Z Blog Entry Research Support http://www2.le.ac.uk/staff/working/research-support/research Explore the services and resources available to support your research at the University. You might also be interested in information about the University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds research.

Get help with funding, grants\ufffd\ufffdand contracts

The Research Support Office supports research grant applications and awards (public sector, EU and charity) and provides research-related management information.\ufffd\ufffdEnterprise\ufffd\ufffdand Business Development support work with industry and other commercial partners.

Develop your skills

The Leicester Learning Institute supports the initial and continuing professional development of both research staff and students \ufffd\ufffd\ufffd in close collaboration with the Graduate School for the postgraduate community.\ufffd\ufffdThe Library provides training and guidance in accessing, managing and sharing information for research. IT training is available from IT Services.

Manage your research data

What would you do if you lost your research data tomorrow?\ufffd\ufffdGet help with managing your research data.\ufffd\ufffdFind out about information security.

Manage your research profile in IRIS

The University Integrated Research Information System (IRIS) enables you to store information on your publications, professional activities and working relationships all in one place. This information is also used to support REF2014, research council post-award monitoring and departmental reviews.

  • More information about the system (log-in required).

Publish and share your research

Get advice on open access publishing. Make your research paper or thesis available from the Leicester Research Archive.

Recruit research students

Advice is available from the Marketing\ufffd\ufffdand Communications Office.

Research strategy\ufffd\ufffdand governance

  • Research Policy Committee
  • Research strategy (PDF)
  • Research ethics
]]> No publisher mc234 research 2009-12-16T10:40:00Z Page Participant Panel http://www2.le.ac.uk/departments/psychology/panel/panel Information about the participant panel and details of current studies requiring volunteers. Participating in Research

The School of Psychology is often in need of volunteers to participate in research. This page provides information about these opportunities and includes an on-line form for signing up as a volunteer. If you sign up you may receive emails asking whether you would like to participate in specific projects.

If you are a student of the University, or if you live in or near Leicester, UK, you may also be able to participate in experiments at the University of Leicester. Some of our research is conducted on-line, and some is done through postal surveys, and you can take part in these wherever you are located. A few of our projects include small payments to cover participants' expenses and some also include cash rewards.

The experiments are interesting and fun, and participants are always given information about the purpose of the research and results. If you would like to volunteer, please fill in and submit the very short on-line form, and we will contact you when we need participants. The experiments listed below will give you an idea of what we are doing, and if you sign up as a volunteer you may be invited to participate in one or more of those projects or others that are not yet listed.

Click here to fill in the Participant Panel Volunteer Form

Current projects requiring attendance at the University of Leicester

None currently running.

\ufffd\ufffd

Click here to fill in the Participant Panel Volunteer Form

Current projects on-line

Driving hazard task

The aim of this study is to gauge where drivers expect certain hazards to appear in a driving scene.

Participants are\ufffd\ufffdpresented with a number of statements describing a driving scenario in which a hazard is designated. They are then presented with an image of a driving scene where the hazard is absent and\ufffd\ufffdthey\ufffd\ufffdneed to click on where they expect that hazard to occur. The experiment takes about 20 minutes to complete.

To participate in the study you must be 18 years or older and hold a full UK driver's licence. If you would like to take part please visit:

https://psycserver.le.ac.uk/drivingHazard/

Perceived fear of crime

The purpose of this project is to evaluate attitudes and beliefs about the perceived level of 'fear of crime' experienced by University social science undergraduate students. This research is being undertaken to establish if a similar group of individuals working within a forensic psychology setting have varying attitudes and beliefs in relation to the perceived fear of crime.

After answering a series of\ufffd\ufffd rateable questions participants will be asked to answer four open questions in their own words. These questions\ufffd\ufffdaim to examine individual's attitudes and beliefs\ufffd\ufffdin relation to crime\ufffd\ufffdin more depth. In total the online task should take approximately 15 minutes.
If you experience any difficulties completing the questionnaire, or have any questions or concerns about this research please contact Paul Hunter on\ufffd\ufffd pah27@le.ac.uk.
\ufffd\ufffd
The URL for the study is:\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd
https://www.surveymonkey.com/s/3652TNQ

Current postal surveys\ufffd\ufffd

None currently running.

Click here to fill in the Participant Panel Volunteer Form

]]> No publisher pcweb1 psychology research participant 2009-09-18T12:55:00Z Page Research Staff http://www2.le.ac.uk/offices/lli/rd/career-development/research-staff/research-staff There are approximately 450 research staff at the University of Leicester, largely concentrated in the Colleges of Medicine, Biological Sciences and Psychology, and Science and Engineering. Research staff perform a variety of roles and responsibilities and are crucial to the University\ufffd\ufffd\ufffds research output.

The University is a signatory to the Concordat to Support the Career Development of Researchers which aims to improve the employment experiences and institutional support for research staff, and holds an \ufffd\ufffd\ufffdHR Excellence in Research\ufffd\ufffd\ufffd award in recognition of its ongoing commitment to researcher development.

In addition, we provide a programme of University-wide and personalised support to research staff across the organisation, and aim to support all career aspirations, and all career stages.

Training and development for research staff

Research staff can participate in all training courses offered by the Leicester Learning Institute. In addition, there are a number of short workshops, designed to provide timely and impartial support for research staff to reflect on their career development:

  • Research staff careers: a facilitated discussion
  • Enhancing your CV: create a structure to tell your career story
  • Transferable skills: how to recognise and value them
  • Assertiveness for research staff
  • Moving your career in the right direction
  • Impact and Influence

Policy and organisational development

A number of mentoring schemes are in operation to provide personalised support for career development and other research-related questions.

The Concordat Steering Group oversees the implementation of the University of Leicester Action Plan 2013-2015, and reports to the Research Policy Committee.

The University of Leicester participates in the Careers in Research Online Survey. The survey will run again in 2015 and informs the development of researcher development provision across the University.

The work of the Concordat Steering Group complements the implementation of departmental Athena SWAN action plans.

Resources and external links

  • The Concordat to Support the Career Development of Researchers
  • Researcher career stories
]]> No publisher jd68 survey researcher support research career development 2009-04-27T08:45:00Z Page Careers in Research Online Survey (CROS) http://www2.le.ac.uk/offices/lli/rd/career-development/research-staff/cros CROS\ufffd\ufffdis a national survey,\ufffd\ufffdmanaged by Vitae\ufffd\ufffdand\ufffd\ufffdadministered through the Bristol Online Surveys tool.

The survey is completely anonymous and\ufffd\ufffdgathers the views of research staff about working conditions, career aspirations and career development opportunities. The questions\ufffd\ufffdreflect the principles of the Concordat to Support the Career Development of Researchers.\ufffd\ufffd

University of Leicester CROS

The last administration of the CROS at the University of Leicester was in July and August 2011, with follow-up focus groups in\ufffd\ufffdFebruary 2012. The findings of the survey and focus groups were reported to the Concordat Steering Group. The survey will run again in Leicester in 2015.

You can view the most recent UK-wide aggregate CROS results\ufffd\ufffdhere.

\ufffd\ufffd

]]> No publisher jd68 researcher support research career development survey 2009-04-27T08:45:00Z Page
